channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: U.S. Government Shutdown Sorely Tests National Security State
item.description: One month into federal funding shortfall, U.S. defense and diplomacy resources are being stretched.

item.title: U.S. Gunboat Diplomacy Will Only Embolden China
item.description: Trump’s aggression in Latin America has given a powerful boost to Beijing in the Pacific.

item.title: China vs. the U.S.: Who Will Win Over ASEAN?
item.description: Beijing is hoping to use an expanded free trade deal to portray itself as the bloc’s alternative to the United States.

item.title: Donald Trump’s trade power is vast, but self-defeating
item.description: The view from Canada, as Trumpian threats fly

item.title: Is the AI Economy a Bubble?
item.description: Economist Jared Bernstein warns that revenues simply aren’t catching up with sky-high valuations.

item.title: We’ve Forgotten What ‘Soft Power’ Is
item.description: Internationalists are mourning the loss of soft power. Do they even know what that means anymore?

item.title: Netanyahu Orders Immediate Strikes on Gaza
item.description: The fragile cease-fire is once again at risk of collapsing as Israel accuses Hamas of violations.

item.title: Why There’s No Easy Button to End the Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: Economic carrots and sanctions aren’t powerful enough to compensate Russia for giving up its maximalist aims.

item.title: How pig organs may soon save lives
item.description: After a man lives nearly nine months with a pig kidney, two American firms are preparing clinical trials

item.title: What the Trump-Xi meeting can and can’t solve
item.description: Expect the outcome of the meeting to be a truce—not a treaty

item.title: How Turkish Arms End Up in African Conflicts
item.description: Ankara’s engagement on the continent has generated violence, not stability.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa is one of the strongest storms ever recorded
item.description: Jamaica and Cuba are in its path

item.title: Weight-loss drugs are spreading across the world
item.description: The expiry of patents in China, India and elsewhere will boost uptake dramatically

item.title: A political drama for the ages, opening soon in New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani v Donald Trump. What could go wrong?

item.title: Central Europe Has Compassion Fatigue
item.description: Nearly four years of hosting Ukrainian refugees is fueling a resentful backlash.

item.title: China is backing Russia’s war to keep America distracted, says Kaja Kallas
item.description: China’s rulers want to show it is in their people’s interests to keep America focused on Europe, according to the EU’s foreign-policy chief

item.title: What AI Means for Growth and Jobs
item.description: While many commentators warn that AI will undermine employment and offer only modest productivity gains, empirical studies continue to suggest otherwise. With the right policies in place, the technology holds immense potential to drive both growth and employment.

item.title: No Kings Means No Barons
item.description: Turning the spotlight on the King while letting the barons off the hook will not stop Donald Trump and his copycats from amassing feudal powers. The illusion of the strong man who will fix everything cannot be dispelled by reviving the illusion that oligarchy offers the population democratic choices.

item.title: Prosecuting the Powerful
item.description: Historical data shows putting leaders on trial is a healthy democratic practice.

item.title: The Trump-Xi APEC Summit: Seeking a Trade Truce
item.description: The meeting is less about reaching a “grand deal” and more about achieving a ceasefire – a trade truce to stabilize expectations and buy time.

item.title: TICAD9: A New Direction and New Challenges
item.description: Africa and Japan are forging a new path ahead of the upcoming G-20 meeting in Johannesburg.

item.title: In First Summit, Takaichi Uses Abe Legacy, Flattery, and Defense Plans to Engage Trump
item.description: Japan’s willing compliance with U.S. defense demands could boost its strategic autonomy (and weaken the alliance) in the future.

item.title: The Countries Courting Trump With Critical Minerals
item.description: From Japan to Pakistan, the deals keep coming.

item.title: The Lessons of ‘A House of Dynamite’
item.description: Kathryn Bigelow’s latest movie offers insights for an increasingly dangerous world.

item.title: Democratic Peace Theory, R.I.P.
item.description: The rise, and potential fall, of a mainstay academic theory.

item.title: Democratic Peace Theory, R.I.P.
item.description: The rise, and potential fall, of a mainstay academic theory.

item.title: The ‘New Normal’ Is Not Deglobalization, It’s Reglobalization
item.description: In places like Uzbekistan, policymakers have doubled down on economic liberalization and internationalization despite Western narratives of global conflict and economic decoupling.

item.title: Corruption and Cybercrime in Southeast Asia: The United Nations Fights Back
item.description: Corruption, cybercrime, and organized crime must be tackled together to upend the scam industry.

item.title: Rethinking Offense and Defense in the AI Era
item.description: China’s unmanned vessel, the Zhu Hai Yun, highlights the blurred line between offense and defense in AI-enabled warfare.

item.title: Will AI Bury Future Generations in Cognitive Debt?
item.description: As companies seek to automate repetitive tasks in the name of cost-cutting, they should consider the longer-term implications. If we transfer all codified knowledge to machines, we will bequeath to future generations a world where it will be ever harder to learn by doing, to achieve mastery, and thus to aspire to creative freedom.

item.title: Education with Purpose at The Koç School
item.description: How Turkey's leading K-12 institution blends academic excellence, well-being and global vision to prepare future leaders for a changing world.

item.title: How International Crises Help Authoritarians
item.description: In today’s increasingly multipolar world, the rise of geopolitical conflicts has been a boon for competitive authoritarian regimes. Russia’s war against Ukraine, for example, strengthened the domestic positions of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan ahead of pivotal elections.

item.title: Beleaguered South Asian University Now Accused of ‘Cover-up’ of Alleged Gang Rape on Campus
item.description: Lofty aims accompanied the setting up of this university. Right-wing activism has sullied its image.

item.title: How Bangladesh’s Cricket Hero Buried His Own Career
item.description: Shakib al Hasan’s continued association with the much-reviled Sheikh Hasina prompted the interim government to ban him from playing for the country.

item.title: Has the EU Sacrificed Human Rights to Economic Expediency in Indonesia?
item.description: The Indonesia-EU Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, signed last month, appears to mark a dilution of long-held principles.

item.title: After Prince Group Sanctions, Unanswered Questions for Cambodia’s Interior Minister
item.description: The country's Ministry of Interior denies the hard evidence linking Deputy Prime Minister Sar Sokha to major Prince executives.

item.title: How Trump Can Avoid ‘Owning’ Gaza
item.description: Expanding U.S. strategic ambiguity with both Israel and the Gulf states is the best bet for regional progress.

item.title: How Trump Can Avoid ‘Owning’ Gaza
item.description: Expanding U.S. strategic ambiguity with both Israel and the Gulf states is the best bet for regional progress.

item.title: Toward a Taiwan Truce
item.description: How Trump and Xi can pull back from the brink.

item.title: ASEAN, China Upgrade Free Trade Agreement
item.description: The announcement came after China's Premier Li Qiang called on his Asian counterparts to "uphold free trade and the multilateral trading system."

item.title: Breaking Down Malaysia’s 2026 Budget
item.description: The budget contains few surprises, putting the country in a good position to face the uncertainty of the current global economic climate.

item.title: ASEAN Foreign Ministers Voice ‘Concern’ About Ongoing Myanmar Conflict
item.description: The bloc will reportedly not send observers to the military-administered elections planned for December, but is likely to accept the new status quo that emerges.
